A 8-year-old child weighing 26 kg presents with a history of loose stools for 2 days. On examination, there is severe dehydration. Laboratory investigations are as follows. What is the initial management as per ISPAD guidelines? (NEET PG 2023)

 

RBS → 550

рН → 7.01

Na+ → 158

Urine glucose → 3+

Urine Ketone → +ve
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Manage ABC, NS 10-20 mL/kg and start insulin after 1 hour

 

The given clinical scenario points to diagnosis of diabetic ketoacidosis

 

According to the ISPAD guidelines shown below, first the patient has to be classified for shock/Moderate dehydration/minimal dehydration. In this given scenario, child is in shock, so, the initial management includes management of the airway, breathing, and circulation (ABC) and fluid replacement along with an IV bolus of 20 mL/kg 0.9% Normal saline, followed by an IV insulin infusion of 0.05 - 0.1 U/kg/hr, 1 hour after starting fluid replacement therapy.

 

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Manage ABC, NS 20 mL/kg along with insulin 0.1 IU/kg/hr.: First we will give fluids and then after one hour we will give insulin

 

Option C. Manage ABC, NS 10 mL/kg along with insulin 0.1 IU/kg/hr: The fluid volume of 10 mL/kg is insufficient for severe dehydration and shock. The correct volume is 20 mL/kg.

 

Option D. Manage ABC, NS 30 mL/kg and start insulin after 1 hour: This option provides an insufficient fluid volume and delays insulin administration, which is not recommended in severe cases.

 

Educational Objective:

 

In the management of diabetic ketoacidosis (DKA) in children, the initial treatment includes managing ABC, administering 20 mL/kg of 0.9% normal saline, and starting an insulin infusion at 0.1 U/kg/hr.

questions.text: The following parameter in ALL indicate a poor prognosis: (NEET PG 2018)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Age > 10 years

 

Age >10 years indicates a poor prognosis in ALL.

 

Leukocyte count <50,000/mm, hyperdiploidy, trisomy of chromosomes 4, 10, 17 indicate a better prognosis.

 

 

Educational Objective:

 

In Acute Lymphoblastic Leukemia (ALL), prognostic factors such as age greater than 10 years, WBC count greater than 200,000/mm^3, male gender, presence of CNS involvement, and certain cytogenetic abnormalities such as t(9;22) or t(4;11) are associated with a poorer prognosis compared to their counterparts.

questions.text: A 3-month-old baby with intracranial diffuse calcifications, chorioretinitis, and hydrocephalus. What is the most likely diagnosis?  (NEET PG 2024)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Toxoplasmosis

 

The clinical presentation of intracranial diffuse calcifications, chorioretinitis, and hydrocephalus is characteristic of congenital toxoplasmosis. Congenital toxoplasmosis is caused by the protozoan parasite Toxoplasma gondii. The classic triad associated with this condition includes:

 

  1. Intracranial diffuse calcifications
  2. Chorioretinitis
  3. Hydrocephalus

 

These features are clearly visible in the provided imaging, where multiple calcifications (white dots) are seen throughout the brain, which is typical of toxoplasmosis.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. CMV (Cytomegalovirus): CMV infection in a congenital context typically presents with periventricular calcifications rather than diffuse intracranial calcifications. This means the calcifications are primarily located around the brain's ventricles rather than spread diffusely throughout.

 

 

Option C. Zika virus: Zika virus infection can lead to gray matter and white matter calcifications, which are distinct from the diffuse calcifications seen in toxoplasmosis. Zika is also associated with microcephaly and contractures, which are not noted in this case.

 

Option D. Rubella: Congenital rubella syndrome can present with various symptoms such as cataracts, heart defects, and hearing impairment, but it is not typically associated with intracranial calcifications or hydrocephalus, making it an unlikely diagnosis for this presentation.

 

Educational Objective:

 

The key fact to memorize is that the triad of intracranial diffuse calcifications, chorioretinitis, and hydrocephalus is indicative of congenital toxoplasmosis.

 

Remember:

 

  • Periventricular calcification – Congenital CMV infection
  • Intracranial diffuse calcification - Congenital toxoplasmosis
  • Gray matter-white matter (GMWM) Calcification – Congenital Zika virus

questions.text: A 3-month-old baby comes with complaints of deafness, cataract, and patent ductus arteriosus. Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis? (NEET PG 2023)
questions.solution:
Ans. D) Congenital rubella syndrome

 

The triad of Patent ductus arteriosus (PDA), Cataract and Sensorineural Hearing loss (SNHL) points to a diagnosis of Congenital rubella syndrome

 

Rubella causes most severe form of intra uterine infection. If infection sets within 11 weeks POG – 90% defects, if 11-12 weeks – 33% defects chances. More the weeks pass, less is the frequency of having CRS infections.

 

Presentation is similar like measles rash but rash appears on day 1 & lasts for 3 days (3 days measles)

 

Triad – congenital heart disease (MC – PDA; Least Common – ASD), Cataract and Sensorineural Hearing loss (SNHL).

 

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Congenital herpes simplex virus infection: The transmission of HSV to babies usually occurs during delivery in mothers who develop primary genital herpes at that time. Infected babies may be asymptomatic or have fulminant disease. Presents with vesicular eruption on to skin, eyes and mouth. CNS disease that presents as meningitis with seizures and altered sensorium. Diagnosis is by Tzanck smear of the skin lesions, culture or PCR of lesions or cerebrospinal fluid.

 

Option B. Congenital toxoplasmosis: Congenital toxoplasmosis occurs due to maternal primary infection, which is generally subclinical may lead to fetal infection and disease. The transmissibility increases but the risk of fetal disease decreases with advancing pregnancy. It presents with a triad of chorioretinitis, hydrocephalus, and intracerebral calcifications.

 

 

Option C. Congenital cytomegalovirus infection: Congenital CMV is reported to be the commonest congenital infection. The overall transmission rate with primary infection is 30% and 10% of all babies infected are symptomatic. Congenital infection can affect all organ systems. Periventricular calcification is characteristic. The diagnosis of congenital CMV is confirmed by a positive IgM in the first two weeks of life.

 

 

 

Educational Objective:

 

The triad of patent ductus arteriosus (PDA), cataract, and sensorineural hearing loss (SNHL) is diagnostic of congenital rubella syndrome (CRS).

questions.text: A male child presented with arthralgia and abdominal pain. On examination, there was palpable purpura over the lower limbs. There is a past history of upper respiratory tract infection prior to the onset of presenting symptoms. Which of the following is the treatment for this condition? (NEET PG 2022)
questions.solution:
Ans. D) Glucocorticoids

 

The clinical scenario is suggestive of Henoch Schonlein's purpura (HSP). Glucocorticoids are used to treat HSP.

 

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Azathioprine: Azathioprine is an immunosuppressant that may be used in severe cases of HSP with nephritis, but it is not the first-line treatment for the initial presentation of HSP.

 

Option B. Methotrexate: Methotrexate is used in various autoimmune and inflammatory conditions, but it is not typically used for the treatment of HSP.

 

Option C. Cyclosporine: Cyclosporine is an immunosuppressive agent used in certain conditions, including severe nephritis, but it is not the first-line treatment for HSP.

 

Educational Objective:

 

The primary treatment for Henoch-Schönlein purpura (HSP), particularly with significant gastrointestinal involvement or severe symptoms, is glucocorticoids such as prednisolone.

questions.text:
Choose the most appropriate answer: (INICET NOV 2022)

 

Assertion: In phenylketonuria, the urine has a mousy odor.

 

Reason: The serum levels of tyrosine, dopamine, and norepinephrine are decreased in phenylketonuria.
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Both assertion and reason are independently true statements, but the reason is not the correct explanation for the assertion.

 

  • Assertion: The statement that "In phenylketonuria, the urine has a mousy odor" is true. The mousy or musty odor of the urine in phenylketonuria (PKU) is due to the accumulation of phenylacetate, one of the metabolites of phenylalanine.
  • Reason: The statement that "The serum levels of tyrosine, dopamine, and norepinephrine are decreased in phenylketonuria" is also true. Phenylketonuria is characterized by a deficiency of the enzyme phenylalanine hydroxylase, which converts phenylalanine to tyrosine. Consequently, low levels of tyrosine lead to reduced synthesis of catecholamines such as dopamine, norepinephrine, and epinephrine.

 

However, the reason provided is not the correct explanation for the assertion. The mousy odor in PKU is directly related to the accumulation of phenylacetate, not to the decreased levels of tyrosine or catecholamines.

 

Detailed Mechanism:

 

  • Phenylketonuria (PKU): PKU is an inborn error of metabolism caused by a deficiency of the enzyme phenylalanine hydroxylase or, less commonly, a defect in enzymes responsible for producing tetrahydrobiopterin (BH4). This defect results in impaired conversion of phenylalanine to tyrosine, leading to the accumulation of phenylalanine and its metabolites, such as phenylpyruvate and phenylacetate, which are excreted in the urine.
  • Tyrosine and Catecholamine Synthesis: Tyrosine is a precursor for the synthesis of catecholamines, including dopamine, norepinephrine, and epinephrine. In PKU, the deficiency of tyrosine leads to reduced synthesis of these neurotransmitters.

 

Educational Objective:

 

In phenylketonuria, the mousy odor of urine is due to the accumulation of phenylacetate, while decreased levels of tyrosine and catecholamines are a result of the impaired conversion of phenylalanine to tyrosine. However, the two phenomena are not causally related.

questions.text: Which one among the following has the lowest risk of perinatal transmission? (INICET MAY 2023)
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Rubella


Rubella, also known as German measles, has the lowest risk of perinatal transmission compared to the other infections listed. While rubella can be transmitted to the fetus during pregnancy, especially in the first trimester, and can lead to significant complications such as congenital rubella syndrome (CRS), the overall risk of transmission at the time of birth is lower than for the other infections listed.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. HSV (Herpes Simplex Virus): HSV has a high risk of perinatal transmission, particularly if the mother has an active infection at the time of delivery. Neonatal herpes can result in severe outcomes, including encephalitis and disseminated disease.

 

Perinatal transmission: 25-60% with active genital lesions

Highest risk with primary maternal infection at delivery

Can cause severe neonatal herpes (encephalitis, disseminated disease)

Cesarean section recommended if active lesions

 

Option B. CMV (Cytomegalovirus): CMV is the most common congenital infection and has a significant risk of perinatal transmission. 

Perinatal transmission: 30-40% through breast milk, cervical secretions

Can occur through birth canal or postpartum

Usually asymptomatic in term infants

More severe in preterm infants
 

It can lead to a range of outcomes from asymptomatic infection to severe neurological impairment.

 

Option D. Hepatitis B: Hepatitis B virus (HBV) has a high risk of perinatal transmission, particularly if the mother is HBeAg positive. Without appropriate prophylaxis, many infants born to HBV-positive mothers will become chronically infected.

 

Perinatal transmission: 70-90% if mother is HBeAg positive

20-30% if HBeAg negative

Occurs during delivery through blood/body fluids

Without prophylaxis, leads to chronic infection in 90% of infected infants
 

Educational Objective:
 

Rubella has the lowest risk of perinatal transmission among the options listed, though it can still cause serious fetal complications if transmitted during pregnancy.

questions.text: Unconjugated hyperbilirubinemia, which did not subside even after 3 weeks of birth, was observed in a neonate. On investigating, liver enzymes, PT/INR and albumin levels were normal. No hemolysis was seen on a peripheral blood smear. A drop in bilirubin level was observed within a week after treatment with phenobarbital. What is the most likely diagnosis? (NEET PG 2019)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Crigler Najjar type 2

 

In the case described above, the neonate had unconjugated hyperbilirubinemia that did not subside even after 3 weeks of birth, but had normal liver enzymes, PT/INR, and albumin levels, and no hemolysis was seen on a peripheral blood smear. These findings are consistent with a diagnosis of Crigler-Najjar type 2. The fact that bilirubin levels dropped after treatment with phenobarbital further supports this diagnosis.

 

Crigler Najjar type 2 is an autosomal recessive disease with non-hemolytic unconjugated hyperbilirubinemia caused by homozygous missense mutations in UGT1A1 resulting in reduced (partial) enzymatic activity.

 

  • Causes of unconjugated hyperbilirubinemia- Physiologic (newborn), Crigler-Najjar, Gilbert syndrome, Hemolytic
  • Gilbert syndrome: Partial deficiency of uridine diphosphate glucuronyltransferase (UDPGT) caused by polymorphism. It is more common, affecting 5-10%. It occurs after puberty. It is not associated with chronic liver disease and no treatment is required.

 

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Rotor syndrome: Rotor syndrome is characterized by conjugated hyperbilirubinemia, not unconjugated hyperbilirubinemia, making it an unlikely diagnosis in this case.

 

Option C. Dubin-Johnson syndrome: Like Rotor syndrome, Dubin-Johnson syndrome is also characterized by conjugated hyperbilirubinemia. It presents with a dark liver on gross examination due to the accumulation of pigment, which is not consistent with the findings described.

 

Option D. Crigler-Najjar type 1: This condition is more severe than type 2 and typically presents with extremely high levels of unconjugated bilirubin, leading to a high risk of kernicterus. Patients with Crigler-Najjar type 1 do not respond to phenobarbital treatment, unlike the neonate described in the scenario.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Crigler-Najjar type 2 presents with unconjugated hyperbilirubinemia that responds to phenobarbital, distinguishing it from other forms of hereditary hyperbilirubinemia.

questions.text: A male child with coarse facies, macroglossia, thick lips with hepatosplenomegaly presents with copious mucous discharge from the nose. The most probable underlying diagnosis is? (AIIMS NOV 2018)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Hurler disease.

 

The clinical presentation described, including coarse facial features, macroglossia (enlarged tongue), thick lips, hepatosplenomegaly (enlargement of the liver and spleen), and copious mucus discharge from the nose, is characteristic of Hurler disease. Hurler disease is a severe form of mucopolysaccharidosis type 1 (MPS 1), which results from a deficiency in the enzyme alpha-L-iduronidase. This deficiency leads to the accumulation of glycosaminoglycans, specifically heparan sulfate and dermatan sulfate, in various tissues.

 

Key Clinical Features of Hurler Disease:

 

  • Coarse facial features: The facial appearance is often described as "gargoyle-like" due to the thickening of facial structures.
  • Macroglossia and thick lips: Enlargement of the tongue and thickened lips are common in Hurler disease.
  • Hepatosplenomegaly: Enlargement of the liver and spleen is a typical finding.
  • Corneal clouding: Although not mentioned in the question, this is another characteristic finding in Hurler disease.
  • Skeletal abnormalities: These include joint stiffness, short stature, and skeletal dysplasia.
  • Upper respiratory tract involvement: Patients may experience recurrent respiratory infections, noisy breathing, and persistent nasal discharge.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Beckwith-Wiedemann syndrome: This is an overgrowth syndrome characterized by features such as macrosomia (large body size), macroglossia, hemihypertrophy (asymmetrical body growth), omphalocele (abdominal wall defect), and an increased risk of certain cancers like Wilms tumor and hepatoblastoma. However, the combination of features presented in this case aligns more closely with Hurler disease.

 

Option C. Proteus Syndrome: This is a rare condition characterized by overgrowth of bones, skin, and other tissues. It does not typically present with the features described in the question, such as coarse facies, hepatosplenomegaly, and copious mucus discharge.

 

Option D. Hypothyroidism: While congenital hypothyroidism can present with macroglossia and coarse facial features, it typically does not cause the combination of symptoms described in this case, such as hepatosplenomegaly and persistent nasal discharge.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Hurler disease, a form of mucopolysaccharidosis type 1, presents with coarse facial features, macroglossia, hepatosplenomegaly, and copious nasal discharge, and is caused by a deficiency in alpha-L-iduronidase leading to the accumulation of glycosaminoglycans.

questions.text: A child came to OPD with fever for 6 days with strawberry tongue, conjunctival congestion, and peeling of skin. What should be the ideal treatment? (INICET NOV 2023)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) IVIG

 

  • The constellation of symptoms described (fever, strawberry tongue, conjunctival congestion, and peeling skin) is suggestive of Kawasaki disease. IVIG is a key component of the treatment for Kawasaki disease to reduce the risk of coronary artery abnormalities.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Aspirin: This is also a crucial part of the treatment for Kawasaki disease. Aspirin is used in Kawasaki disease to reduce inflammation and the risk of blood clot formation. However, it is often used in conjunction with IVIG.

 

Option C. Plenty of fluids: While maintaining hydration is important, fluid administration alone is not the primary treatment for Kawasaki disease. The use of IVIG and aspirin is more specific to address the underlying inflammatory process.

 

Option D. Cephalosporins: Cephalosporins are antibiotics and are not the appropriate treatment for Kawasaki disease, which is not caused by a bacterial infection.

 

Educational Objective:  

 

Fever + 4 out of 5 below = Classic Kawasaki

questions.text: A 3-year-old male has the following buccal mucosa finding. After three days, he presents to your OPD with a rash. What is your diagnosis? (NEET PG 2020)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Measles

 

Based on the given information, the most likely diagnosis for the 3-year-old male with buccal mucosa findings followed by a rash after three days is Measles.

 

  • Measles is a viral illness that commonly affects children. It typically starts with flu-like symptoms such as fever, cough, runny nose, and red, watery eyes.
  • One of the hallmark signs of measles is the presence of Koplik spots, which are small, white, grain-like lesions that appear on the buccal mucosa.
  • A rash usually follows the appearance of Koplik spots. This rash typically starts on the face and neck and then spreads to the rest of the body.
  • If you suspect that a child has measles, it is essential to isolate them and refer them to a healthcare facility for further evaluation and treatment.
  • Lymphadenopathy may also be present.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Leukoplakia: Leukoplakia is a benign condition characterized by white patches on the mucous membranes. It is not associated with fever and rash.

 

Option C. Scarlet fever: Scarlet fever is caused by beta-hemolytic streptococci and presents with a URI (upper respiratory infection) and a sandpaper-like rash. It does not have Koplik spots.

 

Option D. Kawasaki disease: Kawasaki disease is an acute febrile illness associated with arteritis of medium to large-sized vessels. It presents with fever, rash, and conjunctivitis but lacks Koplik spots.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Measles is characterized by the presence of Koplik spots on the buccal mucosa followed by a widespread rash, starting from the face and neck.
